WASHINGTON – The House of Representatives approved a bill Friday to decriminalize marijuana, though the measure stands little chance of becoming law this year.

Black Americans are more than three times more likely than white Americans to be arrested for crimes related to marijuana, according to the American Civil Liberties Union, even though use is roughly equal.
Despite bipartisan enthusiasm for the First Step Act, the prison reform bill Congress passed in 2018, there’s not much appetite among Republicans for reforming outdated marijuana laws.
Only a dozen Republicans have cosponsored a separate decriminalization bill, by Rep. Nancy Mace (R-S.C.), that would decriminalize marijuana and regulate it like alcohol.
“Every major urban area has increased crime and Democrats are legalizing drugs and propping up the marijuana industry,” Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) said on the House floor.
The House bill would remove cannabis from the federal list of controlled substances and eliminate criminal penalties for its distribution or possession.
“The only way that we can support ‘legalization’ is if we’re doing this in a way that gets control of marijuana as we now have control of alcohol.”
